column2: giant]].<ref name=RC>[[J.R.R. Tolkien]], ''[[Guide to the Names in The Lord of the Rings
column3: Nomenclature of The Lord of the Rings]]'', omitted entry quoted in [[Wayne G. Hammond]], [[Christina Scull]], ''[[The Lord of the Rings: A Reader's Companion]]'', pp. 536-7</ref>

column1: According to folklore, Tarlang belonged to a group of giants who in "ancient days" were building the [[White Mountains]] in order to prevent [[Men]] from entering the giants' land close by the [[Beleriand
column2: Sea]]. While carrying a heavy load of rocks, Tarlang stumbled and fell on his face, fatally breaking his neck. His corpse was used by the other giants to finish the wall: his remants formed the pass [[Tarlang's Neck]] (from the break in his neck), [[Dol Tarlang]] (consisting of his head), and [[Cûl Veleg]] and [[Cûl Bîn]] (remnants of his load of rocks).<ref name=RC/>

column1: The name ''Tarlang'' is glossed as "stiff neck", consisting of ''[[tarch]]'' ("stiff, tough") + ''[[lang]]'' ("neck").<ref name=RC/><ref name=DW>{{webcite
